user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2 is: A for loop shall be well-formed.
The three clauses of a for statement are the:
1. First clause shall be empty or an expression whose set the value of the loop counter or define and intialize the loop counter.
2. Second clause shall be an expression that has no persistent side effects, and shall use the loop counter and optionally loop control flags, and shall not use any other object that is modified in the for loop body.
3.Third clause shall be an expression whose modify only the value of the loop counter, and shall not use objects that are modified in the for loop body.
4. There shall only be one loop counter in a for loop, which shall not be modified in for loop body. A loop control flag is defined as single identifier denoting an object with Boolean type that is used in the second clause. The behaviour of a for loop body includes the behaviour of any functions called within that statement. 
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtMem2HexFile:
```c
bool UtMem2HexFile(const void *Memory, const char *Filename, uint32 Length)
{
    FILE * fp;
    uint32 i;
    uint32 j;

    if ((fp = fopen(Filename, "w")))
    {
        for (i = 0; i < Length; i += 16)
        {
            fprintf(fp, "   %06lX: ", (unsigned long)i);
            for (j = 0; j < 16; j++)
            {
                if ((i + j) < Length)
                    fprintf(fp, "%02X ", ((uint8 *)Memory)[i + j]);
                else
                    fprintf(fp, "   ");
            }
            fprintf(fp, " ");
            for (j = 0; j < 16; j++)
            {
                if ((i + j) < Length)
                    fprintf(fp, "%c", isprint(((uint8 *)Memory)[i + j]) ? ((uint8 *)Memory)[i + j] : '.');
            }
            fprintf(fp, "\n");
        }
        fclose(fp);
        return true;
    }
    else
    {
        printf("UtMem2HexFile: Error Opening File: %s, %s\n", Filename, strerror(errno));
        UtAssert_True(false, "UtMem2HexFile: Error Opening File");
        return false;
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function UtMem2HexFile:
#define UtAssert_True(Expression, __VA_ARGS__) UtAssertEx(Expression,UtAssert_GetContext(),__FILE__,__LINE__,__VA_ARGS__)
...
UtAssert_CaseType_t UtAssert_GetContext(void)
{
    return DefaultContext;
}
...
typedef uint32_t  uint32
...
typedef uint8_t   uint8
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
for (j = 0; j < 16; j++)
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 14.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the for loop "for (j = 0; j < 16; j++)" meets all clauses of Rule 14.2. The first clause initializes the single loop counter j, the second clause (j < 16) uses only the loop counter and a constant and has no persistent side effects, and the third clause (j++) modifies only the loop counter. The loop body (and the called functions) do not modify j, so there is only one loop counter and it is not modified in the body.
